questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions:
questions.solution:
Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi such as bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea like laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Stridor is an audible respiratory noise that gets produced by turbulent airflow through an obstructed upper airway. It is an inspiratory sound that may have an expiratory component. It is distinct from stertor which is a snoring-like noise produced from an obstructed nasopharynx or oropharynx. 

The intensity and pitch of sounds originating from the respiratory system vary based on their site of origin within the respiratory tract and may be heard with or without a stethoscope. Usually, the pitch of the sound increases, and the intensity decreases as one goes lower into the respiratory tract.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: What is the most common cause of congenital stridor?
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor.

It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. 

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, omega-shaped epiglottis is seen.

questions.text: What is congenital laryngeal stridor also known as?
questions.solution: Laryngomalacia is also called congenital laryngeal stridor. It is the most common cause of stridor in newborns.

questions.text: A 1-week old infant has been diagnosed to have laryngomalacia. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: Most common cause of stridor in newborn

questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia has an excellent prognosis. 

Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in newborns. 

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, omega-shaped epiglottis is seen

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-week old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age.

Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of  severe laryngomalacia include:

  • Difficulty feeding
  • Increased effort in breathing
  • Poor weight gain 
  • Pauses in the breathing 
  • Frequent spitting up

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
questions.solution:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis.

It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. 

Diagnosis:

  • In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm.
  • In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm.

The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment:

  • Grade 1: <50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: No lumen detected

Other options

  • Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma.
  • Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system.
  • Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with a swelling on the right side of his neck. The swelling moves with deglutition. On examination, the swelling is compressible and there is a gurgling sound heard on compression. What is his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce’s sign. The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible.

Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition.

Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years.

Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.

questions.text: You are the ENT resident performing a direct laryngoscopy procedure on a patient and report the presence of a laryngocele. The given condition is due to an enlarged diverticulum from which part of the larynx?
questions.solution:
Laryngocele arises from the saccule of the ventricle. It is an abnormal dilation of the laryngeal saccule and extends beyond the thyroid cartilage and the ventricle.

It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver.

Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization. External laryngocele is managed by excision (external/LASER).

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-month-old infant to the ENT department with complaints of difficulty in breathing. On examination, you notice  biphasic stridor. Rigid bronchoscopy shows subglottic hemangioma. Which of the following is not included in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is of congenital subglottic hemangioma. Embolization is not preferred in congenital laryngeal conditions. All congenital laryngeal conditions tend to regress with growth.

The principal management is conservative as many hemangiomas involute spontaneously. Depending on the status of the airway, treatment can involve:

  • To wait and watch
  • Steroid therapy
  • Tracheostomy and observation

If the condition does not regress with time, the modalities of treatment include:

  • LASER excision
  • Laryngofissure and excision
  • -pexy and -plasty procedures (epiglottopexy, supraglottoplasty, etc)

questions.text: A 30-year-old singer complains of a change in her voice. Direct laryngoscopy procedure shows the presence of laryngeal cysts. Which part of the larynx does the cyst arise from?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal cysts arise in the aryepiglottic folds. 

These are benign conditions that need no intervention unless they are large. Large cysts can cause airway obstruction/change in voice. These require immediate aspiration followed by deroofing.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
questions.solution:
The image showing grape-like projections, involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts a laryngeal papilloma.

Laryngeal papilloma is a benign tumor of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They can occur in children, most commonly around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile papillomatosis), as well as in adults. They involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy. 

Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as juvenile papillomatosis.

Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision.

The image below depicts laryngeal papillomatosis on laryngoscopy:

Reinke's edema (Option A) is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. 

The laryngoscopic image below shows Reinke's edema:

questions.text: A 5 year old with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with chronic hoarseness (3 months) of voice and respiratory distress for 2 weeks suggests the diagnosis of respiratory papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis). 

Croup (Option A) and acute epiglottitis (Option D), which cause acute upper respiratory tract obstruction, are ruled out due to the chronic nature of the symptoms. In croup, the upper airway obstruction becomes apparent after 1 to 3 days of low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and pharyngitis. On the other hand, in epiglottitis, a child experiences respiratory distress within hours of developing a fever.

Vocal nodules (Option C) are not typically associated with respiratory distress. 

Respiratory papillomatosis is the most common respiratory tract neoplasm in children. They are simple warts (benign tumors) caused by human papillomavirus types 6 and 11 commonly seen in children aged 3 to 5 years.

The course involves remissions and exacerbations of recurrent papillomas, mostly affecting the glottic area (vocal cords), and supraglottis. The patient presents with progressively worsening hoarseness, sleep-disordered breathing, dyspnea, stridor, and severe airway obstruction if left untreated.

Diagnosis confirmed by direct laryngoscopy, which shows grape-like projections (shown below), and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision. Antivirals like interferon alpha2a, ribavirin, cidofovir, and acyclovir are used as adjunct therapies. 

Other options:

Option A: Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The patient initially presents with an upper respiratory tract infection (rhinorrhea, pharyngitis, cough, low-grade fever) followed by a characteristic barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor.

Option C: Vocal nodule (singer’s or screamer's nodule) occurs as a result of chronic vocal abuse. They appear symmetrically at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two third of the vocal cord. The patient presents with chronic hoarseness and voice fatigue.

The image below shows symmetric vocal nodules:

Option D: Acute epiglottitis is caused by streptococcus pyogenes, pneumococci, Hemophilus influenzae, and staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by an acute rapidly progressive course of high-grade fever, dyspnea, and stridor.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation
